content: In this exercise, with $T$ defined by $T(\mathbf{x}) = A\mathbf{x}$, find a vector $\mathbf{x}$ whose image under $T$ is $\mathbf{b}$, and determine whether $\mathbf{x}$ is unique.\[\quad A = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 & -2 \-2 & 1 & 6 \3 & -2 & -5 \\end{bmatrix}, \quad\mathbf{b} = \begin{bmatrix}-1 \7 \-3 \\end{bmatrix}\].

In this exercise, assume that $T$ is a linear transformation. Find the standard matrix of $T$. \T \colon \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^2 \text{ rotates points (about the origin)} \\text{through } \frac{3\pi}{2} \text{ radians (counterclockwise).}

Let $T \colon \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^2$ be a linear transformation that maps\[\mathbf{u} = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \ 2 \end{bmatrix} \text{ into } \begin{bmatrix} 2 \ 1 \end{bmatrix}\]and maps\[\mathbf{v} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \ 3 \end{bmatrix} \text{ into } \begin{bmatrix} -1 \ 3 \end{bmatrix}.\]Use the fact that $T$ is linear to find the images under $T$ of $3\mathbf{u}$, $2\mathbf{v}$, and $3\mathbf{u} + 2\mathbf{v}$.

For this exercise, find all $\mathbf{x}$ in $\mathbb{R}^4$ that are mapped into the zero vector by the transformation $\mathbf{x} \mapsto A\mathbf{x}$ for the given matrix $A$.\[\quad A = \begin{bmatrix}1 & -4 & 7 & -5 \0 & 1 & -4 & 3 \2 & -6 & 6 & -4 \\end{bmatrix}\].

fill in the missing entries of the matrix, assuming that the equation holds for all values of the variables.\[\quad \begin{bmatrix}\bullet & \bullet & \bullet \\bullet & \bullet & \bullet \\bullet & \bullet & \bullet \\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}x_1 \x_2 \x_3 \\end{bmatrix}= \begin{bmatrix}3x_1 - 2x_3 \4x_1 \x_1 - x_2 + x_3 \\end{bmatrix}\].

In this exercise, show that $T$ is a linear transformation by finding a matrix that implements the mapping. Note that $x_1, x_2, \dots$ are not vectors but are entries in vectors.\[\quad T(x_1, x_2, x_3, x_4) = (0, x_1 + x_2, x_2 + x_3, x_3 + x_4)\].

Let \[\mathbf{e}_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \ 0 \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{e}_2 =  egin{bmatrix} 0 \ 1 \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{y}_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \ 5 \end{bmatrix}, \quad 	ext{and} \quad \mathbf{y}_2 =  egin{bmatrix} -1 \ 6 \end{bmatrix},\]and let $T \colon \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^2$ be a linear transformation that maps $\mathbf{e}_1$ into $\mathbf{y}_1$ and maps $\mathbf{e}_2$ into $\mathbf{y}_2$. Find the images of \[\begin{bmatrix} 5 \ -3 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \ x_2 \end{bmatrix}.\].

Let \[\mathbf{x} =  egin{bmatrix} x_1 \ x_2 \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{v}_1 =  egin{bmatrix} -2 \ 5 \end{bmatrix}, \quad 	ext{and} \quad \mathbf{v}_2 =  egin{bmatrix} 7 \ -3 \end{bmatrix},\]and let $T \colon \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^2$ be a linear transformation that maps $\mathbf{x}$ into $x_1\mathbf{v}_1 + x_2\mathbf{v}_2$. Find a matrix $A$ such that $T(\mathbf{x})$ is $A\mathbf{x}$ for each $\mathbf{x}$.
Let $T \colon \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^2$ be a linear transformation such that\[T(x_1, x_2) = (x_1 + x_2, 4x_1 + 5x_2).\]Find $\mathbf{x}$ such that $T(\mathbf{x}) = (3, 8)$.
Let $T \colon \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^3$ be a linear transformation such that\[T(x_1, x_2) = (x_1 - 2x_2, -x_1 + 3x_2, 3x_1 - 2x_2).\]Find $\mathbf{x}$ such that $T(\mathbf{x}) = (-1, 4, 9)$.
